div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: CRIMINALITY IN EGYPT.
div.p: The judgment delivered by the special court against the prisoners tound guilty of a murder- 008 assault on British officers has been criticised on the ground of its great severity. Severe it undoubtedly was; but severity was in this onso absolutely necessary. A display of leniency would have been ill-timed and dange rons; indeed, we will go so far as to say that it might have gravely compromised the security of official and non-official Europeans in many provincial areas. Whatever the Nationalist Press may say, the majority of landowners and of respectable cultivators are heartily in accord with the judgment.
It is almost a literary convention to describe the fellah as a mild and peaceful cultivator. The description is becoming less and less in

barmony with the facts in certain districts. The worst of these is Menoufieh province, which has long had a disreputable pre-eminence in the criminal statistics, and where murder, cattle poisoning, cotton palling, and assaults on the person have been unpleseantly frequent daring the last five or six years.

It may be asked-and with justice-whether this increase in crime does not betoken certain weaknesses in the Administration. That the Ministries of the Interior and of Justice have made occasional administrative errors need not be disputad. Bat the true causes of this steady increase in criminality are the unsuitability of the version of the Code Napoléon which has been adopted by the Egyptian Government to the existing conditions, and the inadequacy of the penalties usually inflicted. In 1884 a civilised legal system was imposed upon a country where for all practical purposes there had been no law but the will of the ruler and his satellites. Corporal punishment-previous'y employed in nine cases out of ten as a means to extract taxes or evidence from the peasants-was abolished. The popalation, relieved from its cruellest burdens and delighted by the prospect of at last resping what it had sown, gave little trouble for some years. A few gangs of robbers had to be honted down, affrays between hostile villages occurred as they occurred in Lane's days, but it was was not till the later 'nineties that the peasants began to form a correct estimate of the risks that attended criminality. In plain language, they realised that they found the length of the law's foot. Judges, who gave sentence in accordance with the evidence, must be supplied with such evidence as would almost compel them to give the prisoner the benefit of the doubt. The result we know. Evidence was manufactured, and in the Native Courts to-day perjary is universal and too Irequently successful. When accuser and aceased bwear falsely as a rule, extort evidence by bribes and threats, and hash the inoonvanient witness by the menace of a trumpedup charge or of personal violence, the task of the judges is rendered appallingly diffioalt. The native judge is inclined to err on the side of leniency. The British judge,. handicapped by the want of knowledge of the people and the language that is inevitable st the outset of his career, is inclined to dis miss many a case on the ground of insufficient evidence.

A case will show the lengths to which the Egyptian criminal is prepared to go in the fabrication of evidence. It occurred at Denishwai. Darwish Zahran, one of the four men recently executed, baaring a grudge against a neighbour, dug up the body of a young girl from the village cemetery, threw it into his enemy's "sakieb," and attended by numerous witnesses discovered the corpse and denounced the luckless owner of the waterwheel on a charge of murder. His enemy, Mahfouz, was fortunate in that the judgment, owing to information received from an accomplice of the chief witness, went in his favour Hassan Mahfouz, who himself boasted an uneviable record, was one of Zahran's com panions on the scaffold at Dani-hwai! It is unnecessary to multiply instances. Mr. Ma obell's note in Lord Cromer's report for 1905 may be studied with advantage by those who require information on the subject. The respectable inhabitants of almost any loca lity are often unwilling to make any complaint to the authorities-they fear reprisals, and in some cases their fears are well grounded. Moral and physical courage are alike rare among the peasants. The possessors of both make perfect omdebs, but unhappily there is not enough of them. The position has its risks. Two omdehs have been murdered in Behers and three in Menoufieh during the past six weeks.

An extensive modification of the present intricate Code may be an impossibility. Bat it surely is not impossible to restore the only punishment, death excepted, which the fellah fears. We refer to flogging. For years the ondehs and sheikhs of villages, the large land owners and notables, and an increasing proportion of the British and native officials have demanded or suggested the revival of corporal punishment inflicted under proper supervision upon persons found guilty of the more brutal forms of personal assault. The native criminal does not enjoy penal servitude, but refers to ordinary imprisonment as a stay in "Coles Pacha's lokanda" and greatly appreciates the fact that he is there supplied with food, medical attendance, and baths. Pain he dreads almost more than death, and if violent crime is to be put down, no menace will be more potent. The only possible alternative is co fisca'ion of property, and the objections to this penalty are obvious enough. For one thing many oriminals have no property to be confiscated; fines are useless; the pris ner refuses to pay and goes to gaol rather than part with a piastre. The reintroduction of the kourbach may be criticised as a retrograde measure, but, after all, what else will deter rustic criminals of the type of the Danishwai fellaheen whose usual, taunt is "Ma kantish abadan mahbous" ie, "You were never in gaol," Educate, educate, ays the humanitarian reformer. But at present we have not the edacators for the towns, much less for the fe'labeen.

Boundary Commission.
The credit opened for the expenses of the Bgyptian officials on the Boundary Commis sion amounts to L.E. 3,000.
Hashish Selure.
The Coast Guards confiscated yesterday afternoon quantity of hashish which a Turk was attempting to smaggle off the S.S. Ismailia.
Cattle Plague.

During the week ending on the 1st inst., fourteen oses of cattle plague were reported; one at Kaabi, Senouris district, one at Minshah, Fayoum, three at Sheikh Zein el Din, three at Chanki, and three at Rahaina.
Florio-Rubattino.

The Fiorio-Rabattino S.S. Bosforo, which went to Benghazi to aid in the salvage of another steamer of the company, returned to Alexandria this morning and will sail for Brindisi, Bari, Areons, and Venice to-morrow at 3 p.m.
Alhambra Theatre.

The Castellano Italian opers company, which has been having such a successful season at the Abbas Theatre, Cairo, will open at the Alhambra Theatre on Monday next with Pac- cini's Tosca. The merits of the company are already well known to our readers.
Libel Appeal Successful.

Ahmed Eff. Paad, proprietor and editor of "Al-Saikeh, who was recently sentenced by the Cairo Native Court of First Instance to six months' imprisonment with hard labour for his attacks against the late Ibrahim Bey Moweilhi, was yesterday declared not guilty of libel by the Native Court of Appeal, Cairo.
Dismissed and Suspended.

A council of discipline of the Ministry of the Interior has decided to dismiss Beyoumi Eff. Fakhi, physician in Kasr-el-Aini Hospital, for disobedience to orders, and to suspend Moha med Eff. Maber, inspector in the Public Health Department, for two months without salary; and Bersoum Eff. Hanna, mawin of the Assonan slinghterhouse, for three months without salary.
All Saints,' Cairo.

We are sorry to learn from All Saints' Church Magazine that the organist, Mr. Peacock, has been suffering from a severe attack of typhoid fever. He has been overtaxed lately, and has not taken his leave when it was due, but ba done heavy extra work during the vacations. He was ill for some weeks in Miss Janes's Home, but thanks to good nursing, he and Mrs. Peacock have been able to go home, and we trust he will return in October in his accustomed health.
Cinematophone Theatre.

The most popular form of entertainment at Alexandria at present seems to be the cinema- tograph, and the latest addition to the number is the Cinematophono Theatre, which opened at the Zizinis last evening. Making dae allow- ance for the shortcomings of a first night, we may say that the "performance" was a great success, and the Zizinis, which, by the way, is excellently ventilated by electric fans, should draw crowded houses for some time. The most interesting items on the programme, owing to their "actualité," were the films representing, King Alfonso's marriage procession and the bull-fight before their Majesties., The cinema- tophono selections from Il Trovatore and Rigoletto are well worth hearing, and alone repay a visit to the theatre.
A Brave Convict.

A Khedivial decree has been issued pardoning the convict Said Bishr, sentenced some 30 months ago to five years' hard labour. Said Bishr obtained his release by an act of signal courage, A train carrying stones had been left by its driver on a sloping descent near the quarries. The brake was forgotten and the train began to descend the slope at an increasing speed. Half-a-mile away a num- ber of convicts were asleep on the line. Said Bishr, realising their danger, succeeded in springing on the engine at imminent risk to his own life, hampered as he was by the leg chain and ball, and shut off steand just in time to save his fellow-convicts. M. René Carton de Wiart Bey, Governor of Tourab convict prison, brought the act to the notice of the authorities, and Said Bishr is now a free man.

div.head:
HUNTED DOWN.
SEARCH FOR DENISHWAI FUGITIVES
TRIAL OF ON BASHI
div.p: Out of the fifty-nine villagers who were accused by the general charge of having taken part in the attack on British officers on the 13th inst, it will be remembered that seven have not as yet been caught. We learn that a most rigorous search for these men is still being carried on, and that in the event of their being found they will be tried on the same charge as the other acenred. We are unable to state at present, however, whether the trial will be held by a similarly constituted special tribunal or by the ordinary Native Courts, though it is presumed that it will be by the former.

We understand that the onbashi, of police who accompanied the officers, and who was guilty of gross perjury before the special tribunal, has been placed under arrest, and that he will very shortly be tried by court- martial for neglect of daty in not carrying ont the orders of the officers and in making no attempt to quieten the mob.

It is also said that the omdeh of Denishwai will be called before the court of omdebs and arraigned for having failed to take the custom- ary steps to ensure order and to protect the officers in their pursuit of pigeon shooting.
The six prisoners, condemned by the special court to penal servitude and hard labour, have been removed to Liman Terreh. prison.
It is said that the Government intends to classi'y Denishwai as an ezbet, instead of village, and the new ezbet will be under the omdehship of Abou Killis village.

div.head: THE LESSON OF DENISHWAL
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE Sir,-The Denishwai incident is closed and after a period of intense excitement there is a general wish to hear no more of a disagreeable subject. But whatever may be our wishes Denishwai has left its mark on the country and some little good may come out of much evil if we can read its lesson aright.

First, we may take it as a rude check to the optimistic school. Clearly, prosperity,diminished taxation, and fair treatment has had no miraculous effect, upon the tellab. He has disappointed some of our local rulers and a certain section of the public at home by a sudden relapse into ignorant brutality-and his mental equilibrium bas only been restored by the application of a proportionately severe corrective. Perhaps the belief that- half a generation had sufficed to civilize the fellah when our own people had occupied some centuries in the process, was a little too radiantly optimistic to be seriously held, but it is undeniable that amongst certain eminent persons in this country there had been some self delusion on this point. Perhaps the wish was father to the thought. At any rate there has been a rude awakening, and now it has been demonstrated that gratitude and love of our rule are factors which cannot be relied on in the government of this country.

Secondly, we must expect a reaction in favour of what has been bluntly called the "damned nigger" school. Many wild and whirling words have been spoken and applauded in the last few weeks. "We must put the natives in their proper place," or "We must teach them that they are not as good as we are," or "These people only understand force." These and such like phrases have been heard on all sides, and accepted by many otherwise. sane, clear-headed persons as "the lesson of Denishwai." Such opinions are never likely to prevail with the responsible heads of the admi- nistration in this country, but they are never- theless of value as showing how little fitted a certain type of Englishman is for colonial administration.

This reactionary feeling is greatly strength- ened by an impression which, rightly or wrongly, has got abroad. Certain incidents have led the public to believe that the Govern- ment is only too glad of the opportunity of punishing and publicly disgracing officials, who in the exercise of very difficult duties and ander the greatest provocation have exceeded the limits of moral saasion. Bratality doubtless En all forms must be discouraged, but there are Occasions when the approved method of "turning the other cheek and then drawing up a procès-verbal against the offender" bringe all Government into contempt.

Lastly, even if we succeed in steering a middle course between dangerous sentimentality on the one hand and force untampered by sympathy on the other, there is still one thing needful more sight, more knowledge of what the Government is doing and what it is about to do, more free discussion, le s obscurantism amongst officials, more consulta tion with the various interests concerned.

Once a year Lord Cromer takes the pablic into his confidence, freely discussing the situation and his policy in dealing with it. If this confidence could commence à little lower down in the official-scale and free discussion and criticism on all Government measures be encouraged, a body of public opinion, English, foreign and native, would be gradually formed which would in time filter down to the lowest strata of society and give a firm foundation to our Government. ANGLO-EGYPTIAN.
BECK & CO'S PILSENER BEER
BREMEN.

V. J. FLEURENT, Cairo

div.head: THE DENISHWAI OUTRAGE.
div.p: A PARALLEL EXPERIENCE IN 1864.

Mr. Alfred Dugdale, of Victoria Park, Manchester, has communicated to the "Manchester Gaardian" the following description of an experience that occurred 40 years ago, which is somewhat similar to the recent Denish wai affair, though in the former case the results were happily less serious. He writes:-Porty- two years since, in February, 1864, I began a residence in Egypt which extended over the ten following years. At that time, and within a few years of my arrival in the village of Kalioub, about eight miles north of Cairo, I went out from the cotton-ginning factory where I was employed as engineer, to shoot pigeons. I had noticed a good many about the village, and had been told that they belonged to nobody in particular, and found afterwards that this was partly true. I shortly came across a flock of pigeons, and firing amongst them brought one down. As I ran forward to pick it up I felt a hand on my shoulder and found myself in the custody of an armed cavass, or policeman, who immediately Seized my gun, shot bag, and powder flask and handed them to two companions. They then marched me off unresistingly, and feeling rather amused than alarmed. In a very few minutes I found myself in what I suppose was the police court. I held out some money and signed that I wanted to pay for the bird I had shot, but the officials shook their heads. I knew very few words of the language (Arabic) at that time, but gathered that nothing could be done except to take me to Alexandria to the Brit Consal. Ultimately, however, a young gentleman in official (Stambouli)costume was brought, who spoke English fluently. He asked me why I had shot the pigeon. I replied that I had done it for amuse- ment, and was willing to pay for it if the owner could be found. He told me that the pigeons really belonged to the village, being originally wild but encouraged to come to the tall towers I could see near the village in order that the dung might acon- mulate at the foot of the tower. He then asked me if I had noticed that on the pre vious day several hats in the village had taken fire, and asked it I did not think it quite likely that my shooting had been the cause. I replied that I was sure it had not, for the simple reason that 1 had not been out shooting the day before, adding that I thought I could account for the fires as being the result of spontaneous combus- tion, caused by the accumulation of straw and manure in layers, which were allowed to accumulate on the house-tops through the goats and in some cases donkeys sleeping there, and being ledded down each night with fresh straw on the top of the past day's manure. He said it might be so, but he did not seem to understand my theory. Ultimately I was asked to promise not to shoot in the village any more, which I readily did, upon which my gan, &c., as well As the pigeon, were returned to me, and I was allowed to depart in peace. I was alone, and, not being a military man, had little or no temptation to resist my captorr. ENGLISH SEAMAN DROWNED.
as

div.head: HEROIC ATTEMPT AT RESCUE.
div.p: An inquest was held yesterday by the British Consular Court on the body of Maurice Ham- mond, fireman of the S.S. Rects, who met his death on Sunday afternoon by falling into the water from the railway bridge which crosses the Madmoudieh Canal near the Seamen's Home. The jury found a verdict of "Accidental Death" and added an expression of opinion that it is desirable that a watchman should be placed on the bridge to prevent men from attempting to cross by it.

In the course of the evidence it was shown that a fireman named Andrew Kavenagh, of the 8.8 Sir W. T. Lewis, who happened to be near the spot, promptly dived under the bridge and ultimately succeeded in bringing the body to the surface. Efforts were made to restore ciousness, but in vain.
The coroner and the jury complimented Andrew Kavenagh upon his conduct, which would probably have saved the man's life had he not injured his head in falling.

div.head: KENEH PRISON FIRE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Dear Sir, With reference to your para- graph in the "Gazette" of the 26th inat,, re the fire at Keneh prison, I would like to state that owing to scarcity of water "our fire. brigade" had very little to do with the extin- guishing of the fire, which went out in two hours for the simple reason that everything combustible in the portion of the prison where the fire occurred had been consumed. It is difficult to understand how the Government, which incurred the heavy expense of the new prison construction, could not afford to spend another L.E. 50 in laying a connection to the water-works A SPECTATOR.

div.head:
SUAKIN'S REDOUBTABLE RIVAL
CHEAP COAL
div.p: The import and export trade of the Sudan has now mostly gone to Port Sudan, and the importance of Baakin bas diminished greatly. Goods for the interior of the Sudan all land now at Port Sudan, and the export of gum, etc., is all shipped from Port Sudan, The Sudan Customs have also greatly increased their staff there.

The Sudan Railways are despatebing large quantities of coal daily to Kbartoom and other places for sale to Government Departments and merchants at about half the price which coal cost before when conveyed by the river Nile, Cheap coal will tend to the greater use of machinery in the Sudan.
Another wash out took place yesterday. near Gebeit station, but very little damage was done. Bimbaabi Lord at once went to the spot and put things right.
The steam dredger belonging to Mr. Bencini, the quays contractor at Port Sudan, which was reported some time ago as having sunk, has now being salved, and will be out of the water in a few days.

The Italian gunboat Agostino Barberigo has been at Port Sudan for several days. Her commander left by rail from Port Sudan for Khartoum. As soon as the commander returns to Port Sudan the Agostino Barberigo will leave for Massowah.

div.head: DEVELOPMENT OF PORT SUDAN.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir-The Alexandrian public may like to learn something about the public works comple ted or under consideration at Port Sudan. The land question in this new town is also of importance, and I hope to prove that the Sadan Government, as I understand from my observations, is not inclined to speculation, as has been stated by some writers who do not realise its paternal attitude.
The principal object of the Government is the civilisation and prosperity of the country by cultivation and trade. It opposes that variety of speculation which differs very little from gambling.

The Sudan Government, realising the dan- gerous consequences of unsound speculative enterprises, which after an ephemeral prosperity collapse, decided from the first to oppose their growth for the sake of the work which it is doing in the cause of humanity and the pros perity of the Sudan.

To safeguard the country from this danger the Sudan Government, after ripe reflection, decided to give in lease from next November, the sites at the new town of Port Sudan, and impose such terms on the lessees that specula- tion would in no way be facilitated, but the construction of different buildings which would contribute to the completion of the town and therefore to its commercial progress and to the concentration and exchange of the different products of the country would derive the maximum of benefit.

The new town of Port Sadan will become a link between Europe, the Cape, and India, and a commercial centre where the steady merchant will grow rich through the logical and gradual growth of the prosperity of the country.

Port Sudan as a town is only one year old, and has at present about six thousand inhabi tante. It is laid out on bygienic principles, and contains several public buildings, com- pleted or in course of erection, viz, the public schools, telegraph and post offices, the moudirich, the barracks, the large customs warehouses, the electrical station for the lighting of the town, eto.

The Government intends to build an ex- change in Port Sudan, but it would be more preferable, in my opinion, to reject any such ides. It would be more logical, I think to consider the formation of a Chamber of Commerce under the direct supervision of the Government.

The town is divided by the harbour into two parts, Eastern and Western, which will communicate by an opening bridge of thirty metres. The preliminary work on the bridge has already begun. The work at the docks and barbour is being carried out with feverish activity, the plans for the laying of the streets and for the drainage are completed, and also the schethe for the supply of drinkable water from Khor Arbst. In a short time the work on the electric telodrome for the transport of goal from the seaside to the warehouses will be commenced and in general all the public works are being quietly executed.

In this connection I should like to mention the name of the Director of Works, Kaimakam Kennedy Bey, a man of wide knowledge, great activity, and remarkable administrative ability. The Sudan Government has found in Kennedy Bey, a man whose energy will solve many pro. blems of the Sudan. He is the responsible man in my mind for the choice of a site for the town of Pert Sudan, which is as regards health and position excellent.

div.head:
ENGLAND IN EGYPT.
HANDS. A SWORD IN BRITISH HANDS.
div.p: Continuing his long letter, published in leader form in "Al Zaher," Abou Shadi Bey remarks that England occupied Egypt to suppress a revolution and afterwards began to act as a reforming Power. "Her reforms are deceptive, but we should have supported her views and her policy till the day when we were strong enough to require her to fulfil ber promises. Such was the policy we ought to have followed-the only possible policy for a weak and ignorant race pitted against a strong and enlightened Power, but we followed an absolutely contrary policy, with bad results for ourselves.

"British policy had been cautions enough- no pillars were demolished-a few posts occn- pied by Englishmen when H. H. the Khedive began his reign. At that time Britain had little else in view but the preservation and guardianship of the Suez Canal, upon which depends the safety of the Indian Empire. Had the Egyptians received their new ruler quietly, had they co-operated with the occupying Power, the day of England's withdrawal from Egypt would soon have come. However, the Egyptians lost their heads, utterly failing to realise their position.

"Helbawi Bey published a series of articles in 'Al Mosyad' which caused great excitement among the populace, and the Boglish watched and noted the change. From the day when Helbawi Bey and some of his friends dragged H. H. the Khedive's carriage in triumph before the Morque of Hussein the occupants began to tighten their grasp. British influence meantime increased and our power declined to its present weakness. At present the Nationalist party's strength is non-existent, and England can fetter the Egyptians at her pleasure. The first link of one of these fetters was the creation of the special court to try offences committed against the Army of Occupation. Bat did any member of the Legislative Council request the British Diplomatis Agent to abolish that court by which any punishment could be inflicted without appeal? Did any one go to far as to demand that the court should at least be international in its composition ............ Under the circumstances the court is simply a sword in British hands and a sharp sword." "Al Lewa" covers twalve columns with an article written by Helbawi Bey and published by "Al Mosyad" fifteen years ago. The article was directed against British policy in Egypt, and "Al Lowa" declares that it republishes it to show the public what a remarkable con- version the Bey has experienced.

div.head: THE KUTTABS
div.p: THE GRANTS-IN-AID.

A supplement to Monday's "Official Journal" contains a code of regulations relating to grants-in-aid of kattabs. Theee grants are given to enable the kattabs to develop into elementary schools suited to the requirements of the mass of the people. To be eligible for a grant every kattab inscribed on the registers of the Ministry must be able to show an average attendance of 25 pupils and must be open at any time to inspection by the Minis try. An entrance register and a register of atttendance must be regularly kept by the headmaster. Independently of religious instruc- tion the school curriculam must comprise in- struction in the Arabic language and writing. and in elementary arithmetic, which must follow the lines of a syllabus attached to the decree and must be given regularly in accord- ance with a specimen time table appended therato or a time-table submitted to and approved by the Ministry. Subject to the approval of the Ministry the time table may be modified in accordance with agricultural exigencies. The grants-in-aid will be awarded by the Ministry of Education within the limits of the funds set apart for the purpose after consideration of the reports and recom mendations of the inspectors.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: A native living at Bab Sidra Barrani, near Karmous, was admitted to hospital suffering from plague on Thursday and died on Sunday. Yesterday, a Sudanese was found dead from plague in the same district. The man had been employed at the Gabbari railway station.

Daring the week ending on the 1st July, eleven cases of plague were notified in Egypt, of which one occurred at Alexandria, one in the district of Samalout, Minieh province, and nine in the district of Yems, Ghirgeh province. The nine cares which were notified at Yema all occurred in one family in the village of El Mawatine, and 60 people who had had commu- nication with this family have been placed under close cbservation. Daring the same week nine cases ended fatally, five cares were effec- ted, and seven remain under treatment.
From the beginning of the year until the lat July, 370 cases of plague have been notified, as compared with 127 and 670 during the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904 respec- tively.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. Mitchell Iones has left for England.
Lord Edward Cecil returns on Saturday next.
Major General Bullock, C.B., is leaving for Europe to-day.
Sir Horace Pinching leaves for Europe on the 15th inst.
Chitty Bey left yesterday afternoon for Earope on leave.

Leave of absence, on private affairs, has been granted to the following officers: Bl Miralai Dickinson Bey, Governor,, Blue Nile Province; El Miralai Wilson Bey, Governor, Sennar Province; El Bimbashi Walsh, Junior Inspector, Kordofan Province: El Bimbashi King, Department of Ordnance.
Mr. G. Scott-Dalgleish has gone for a three months' holiday.
Ismail Pacha Yaghen arrived at Alexandria yesterday on his return from Europe by the German mail steamer.
Hasni Bey Yaghen, inspector to the Ministry of Finance, has resigned his office for ressons unknown.

Captain A. P. Churchill, the, Essex Regi ment, having reported his arrival in Bgypt from India, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi, and has been posted to the 1st Battalion.

Captain N.W. Gardner, the Royal Fusiliers, having reported his arrival in Egypt from England, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi, and has been posted to the 15th Sudanese.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: We hear that the Board of the Sacréries Company as reconstituted has been completed by the addition of the following members: M. Perier, head of the Ragot firm of Paris, M. Millet, of the Union Parisienne, Count de Matherel, one of the directors of the Crédit Foncier Egyptien, and M. Lemson.
M. Naus will probably leave for Europe on the 7th inst.
We have received the following circular from the Comité de Défense des Obligataires de la Société Générale des Bucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte :-

Le projet de Concordat présenté par la Société des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'E- gypte, dont le Comité de Défense vous a adressé le tex'e, a été voté, par l'unanimité des créanciers représentés l'Assemblée con- oordataire qui s'est tenue au Caire le 23 Mai dernier.

Si l'on tient compte que sept cents obliga taires, porteur de 11.546 obligations, dont les titres n'ont pas pu parvenir au Caire en temps utile, avaient (l'exception d'un seal) donné mandat à M. Saint-Plancat de voter pour le Concordat, on peut évaluer à près de 45 mil- lions de francs en chiffres rond, le montant des créances dont les porteurs se sont prononcés en faveur du Concordat

Le 2 jain, le Tribunal da Caire a homologué le texte des proportions concordataires. Au- cune opposition ne s'est produite dans les délais légaux et le jugement d'homologation est passé en force de chose jagée, à dater du 20 Jain courant.

La Société des Sucreries vient d'informer le Comité de Défense qu'elle faissit procéder actuellement à l'impression des obligations nouvelles, et que leur échange avec les ancien- nes serait fait dans le plus bref délai possible. Le premier coupon fire intérimaire de 4. francs vient à l'échéanee le 1er Juillet 1906 et sera payé dès la remise des nouveaux titres à ceux des obligataires qui voudront les faire estampiller.

Aussitôt que la Société aura fait connaltre la date et les conditions de l'estampillage des nouveaux titres, prévu par l'article 8 da Con- cordat, les porteurs en seront avisés par les soins da Syndicat des obligations. En effet, le Concordat étant définitivement homologué, le Comité de Défense doit considérer sa mission comme terminée, et laisser an Conseil d'admi- nistration du Syndicat des Obligataires, qui re trouve constitué ipso facto, le soin de veiller sur les intérêts des obligataires, notam- ment en ce qui concerne l'exécution des clauses de cet arrangement.
Le siège social du Comité restera jusqu'à nouvel ordre dans les bureaux de l'Association 5 rue Gaillon, à Paris.

div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Lundi 2 Juillet 1906. A Londres, le Consolidé anglais a clôturé invarié, vendredi et samedi passés, à 88 L'U- nifiée a gagné 1/8 le premier jour, pour baisser de 1/4 le lendemain à 104 3/4. La National Bank et l'Agricole ont perda 1/8 vendredi, à 25 1/2 et 9 1/2, de même que la Daïrs à 17 ct et la Delta Light 11.7/8. Samedi les valeurs égyptiennes sont demeurées inchangées à ces cours, à l'exception de la Delta Light, qui est remontée à 12.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a olôturé vendredi en baisse de 1 franc à 761 et est restée samedi à ce prix. La Banque d'A- thènes a été renseignée à 154.

Influencée par le lourdear des marchés euro- péens et par la liquidation de fin de mois à Alexandrie, où la position de place n'est pas aussi dégagée qu'ici, notre Bourse continue à être calme et sane affaires, avec une certaine tendance à la réaction. Certes, il n'y a plus lien d'appréhender des dépressions marquantes; mais l'inactivité, qui s'accentue d'ordinaire en Juillet, pourrait bien encore amener, pour l'instant, des tassements graduels sur les valeurs dirigeantes, ainsi que sur d'autres. titres.
La National Bank a perda 1/8 à 25 3/3 et l'Agricole 1/16 à 99/16-5/8.
Le Crédit Fonoir s'est alourdi & 761. La Dairs a perdu 1/4 le livre à 16 3/4-13/16.
L'Immobilière afléchi à 362-363. L'action Wardan Estate a gagné 3/16 à 6 1/4 et la part de fondateur 1/8 7 1/8.
L'action Allotment s'est raffermie à 31/8 acheteurs; la part de fondateur est restée à 105-106. L'Union F'oncière a faibli à 6 et l'Im- provements Corportion à 4 9/16.
Les Héliopolis ont été traités à 29; la pirt de fondateur à 87/3-9.
Dans le groups des Hotels, les Egyptian (Baehler) ont clôturé fermes à 5 7/16 ache
teurs.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta ont éé ramenés à 8 1/2 9/16 et les Hooker à 1 1/16. Les Estates sont restés à 1 5/8-11/16. Les Egyptian Constractions se sont inscrites à 1/8-3/16.

Les actionnaires de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. ((Hymenopoulo) sont convo qués ea nouvelle assemblée générale extraor dinaire à Londres pour le 12 Jaillet courant à l'effet de confirmer les résolutions prises par l'assemblée du 26 Jain relativament à la dis- solution de la Société et à la fasion de celle- oi avec la Building Lands Co.

D'autre part, les notionnaires de la Building Lands Co. sont convoqués à nouveau en as semblée extraordinaire à Alexandrie pour le meroredi 18 Juillet à l'effet de statuer défini- tivement sur les resolutions adoptées provi- soirement le 28 Jait dernier, savoir.
1-Si la fasion s'opère par voie de liqui dation de l'Egyptian Trast, cette liquidation devra être faite en Egypte par l'intermédiaire de la Baildings Lands Co.

2-Augmentation du capital social par l'émission de 67,500 actions de £4 ayant rang "pari passu" avec les actions existantes. L'é- mission sera faite au taux de £5. Sur ces 67,500 actions, 60,000 seront échangées contra les 200,000 actions de l'Egyptian Trast, et 7,500 serviront aa temboursement des indem- nités pour la résiliation des engagements pris par le Trust, frais, efo

3-L'intégralité de la prime d'émission, soit £67,500, sera portée à la réserve. La somme de £187,000, admise d'après les con- ditions oi-dessus comme plus-value des pro- priétés du Trust, sers portée en majoration du prix coûtant de ses propriétés, tel qu'il figare au bilan du 31 Mai 1906. Les 7,500 actions précitées seront réservées de préférence aux actionnaires de la Building Lands, à raison de 1 sotion pour chaque 5 actions par eux pos- Bédées.

La Banque d'Orient annonce qu'elle fait des avances sur ses actions, d'ordre et pour compte de la Banque Nationale de Grèse, sur la base de 100 francs par chaque action en- tièrement libérée et au taux d'intérêt de 5% l'an.
Carnet de l'actionnaire./

Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 20.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 3 Juillet 1996.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 b. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre ls men- tion: "Soumission pour travaux de déblaie- ment du croisement route Chatby."

Le cautionnement ou le reça d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 3 juillet 1906 à midi. Toute offre qui ne remp'it pas les condi- tions ci-dessus sera écartér.

RUSSIA.
REVOLUTION FEARED IN SOUTH.
DUMA AND DEATH PENALTY.
EUCHAREST July 2.
A steamer has arrived at Kustenji from Odessa with large number of Russian aristo- cratic personages, who left fearing an imme diate revolution in the South. (Reuter)
ST. PETERSBURG, July 2.

The Dams discussed the abrogation of the death penalty. The tumult prevented the Government representatives from speaking. It was decided to continue the debate until the voting of the project, which was unanimously adopted at 10 p.m.
SUFFERING IN RUSSIA.
(Havas)

ST. PETERSBURG, Jaly 2. The Governmeut has asked the Doma to grant £10,000,000 in order to relieve suffering due to the failure of crops in 27 governments. (Rit)
ARMY REDUCTION. DISBANDING OF 36 BATTERIES. LONDON, July 2.

The "Tribune" nnderstands that it is con- templated disbanding 36 Batteries of Horse and Field Artillery, and in order to make a reduction of 3,000 men in home infantry batta lions to disband the 3rd battalions of the Scots and Coldstream Guards and Manches- ter Regiment. (Reuter
TRANSVAAL CONSTITUTION.
EARLY SATISFACTORY SETTLEMENT. PRETORIA, July 2.
As a result of the West Ridgeway Commis sion both parties in the Transvaal bave agreed to a compromise enabling an early satisfactory rettlement of the constitution question to be made.
NAVAL MANOEUVRES.
(Reuter)

div.head: MIDSUMMER PIXIES.
div.p: Piskies, pixies, or pigseys, are a tribe of elves peculiar to o'd Cornwall, a territory once extending to the eastern edge of Dart- moor, which is still included in the Duchy. They are not elemental spirits, but in mate- rial life were these of the keltio tribes who refused to give up their ancient religion for Christianity, but otherwise lived blameless; hence their sympathy with humanity. Not good enough for Heaven, nor bad enough for bell, their wandering souls were permitted to remain on earth baunting their owa familiar moorlands wooded coombes, and waste ses beaches. In early May and during the reign of the harvest moon they are active. in revel, but their chief festival of the year is held on Midsommer Eve. With the passing of many centuries they have greatly shrunken in size, and are now indistinguish- able, by daylight, from ants, moths, or batter- flies, except by those intimately acquainted with their appearance. A troop of these sprites was bebeld, of late years, by one who bad the gift of such sight, on a sunny, hillside one brilliant summer afternoon. They were dancing amid the heather-bells, climbing tall foxgloves, tumbling queer somersault, cutting fantastic capers, and, as the Cornish saying runs, "laughing like a pisky." This shows them to be a merry race. Apparently they are gradually becoming converted to Christianity, for on Christmas Eve they assemble in the deepest mines to celebrate the Holy season, when solemn, entrancing music may be heard, and choirs of unearthly voices chanting "Nowell: Nowell

They are tricksy elves, skilled in glamour, and illusion. A favourite deceit of theirs is enticing the lonely night traveller into boga by appearing like the light in eottage win- dow, or a man walking with a lantern aerose ground where no haman foot on tread in safety. They steal pretty babies from the'r cradles, leaving ngly changelings in their places. If spoken of disrespectfally, or event mentioned by name, they take violent offence. Hence they are e lled "The Others," the "Small People in Green," or the "Good Folks." At Germol is a green Jane well-known as a resort of fairies. Oacs, on Midsummer Eve, two tinners who worked at Croft Gothal, a mine hard by, were returning late down this Bat-lane aforesaid, and found it fall from end to end of he little people, holding a fair or high fastival. Among the crowd one of the men recognised his own child; for one evening the boy had been as beautiful as could be seen, and next morning was ugly, weazened, and altered. Therefore the Others must have change! him. When relating this tale next day at Croft Gothal, he was saddenly thrown into a deep pit and almost killed. When carried home, his wife, furious at the cause of their misfortunes, exclaimed that the pixies were taxin', tricksy devils." Instantly she fell backwards into the fire, and was burned severely, a convincing proof that these elvas must not be trifled with.

At Treonike, a small hamlet in St. Austell parish, a boy was once beguiled away from his home, lost for many days, and finally, after all hope of finding him had been given up, he was one morning discovered, fast sleep on a tuft of bracken, hard, by his father's cottage door. His own story ran that he had been playing near that spot on the day of his disappearance, when he heard most exquisite music in the air. At first be mistook this for bird-songs, but soon realised that the Little People must be the unseen musicians. Following the sounds, he easily penetrated a thicket whose depths he had never before succeeded in entering; for some invisible guide smoothed the under- growth in his path, while causing thorns and briars to spring up, closer and more matted than formerly, bebind him and on either hand. Also, the music became more and more ravishing. At last he found himself upon the shore of a small lake, which, to his surprise, reflected the sky thick with stars, though it had been full noontide on the common but a short time earlier. Then a lovely lady came through the darkness, tock him by the hand, and led him about un- derground palaces, with crystal arohes glowing with changing tinte, far finer than any ca verns in the deepest mine. There be saw many marvellous sights, feasted on dainties be had never tasted in his life before, gam- bolled or conversed with troops of merry playmates, all beautifully dressed in green. At last he fell asleep from shear weariness, and awoke in the spot where he had first beard the Pisky Minstrels.

The Gamp, a knoll near St. Just, is a noted spot for Pixy revels. Many werthy folks have been privileged to witness their feasts, in a spirit of friendliness, and often ware given valuable presents. But an old miser in this country had his avarice so much in- flamed by accounts of the wonderful treasures displayed by these good neighbours that he determined to intrade upon their high festival of Midsummer Eve despite express warnings not to do so. Accordingly he set, forth, by moonlight so brilliant that the night seemed a softened day. As he advanced towards the Gump he began to hear entrancing yet mysteri- ous masie. He could not tell whether it was in the air or under the earth, if close at his ears or far away, but its influence was strangely compelling. As it was gay or solemn, so was he moved to tears or laughter, and also- obliged to dance fantastically in obedience to its strains. Still he persevered, determined to keep his wits awake and seizs oppor tunities. Then, with a rending, crashing sound the Gump split open, and he saw a vast hall, ablase with many-coloured lights, spread for feasting with plates and vesse's ct gold and jewels. Here the legend gives circumstantial description of the revels,

interesting, but far too long for quota- tion. Meanwhile, the intruder, apparently unnoticed, crept slowly nearer, hat in band, intending to cover with this the royal table, not knowing that thogsands of pixies had cast tiny chains about him. He raised the hat, as a boy catches a batte fly, when a hrill whistle was heard, his hand remained powerless, fixed in the air, and all became dark. Then came whirring coises, as though a swarm of bees darted past. He was racked, pinched, tortured in every limb, pulled to the ground, and, there chained im- moveably, even his tongue tied with cords, so that the sad resource of howling was denied. This continued till the sun arose, when he found himself covered with innumer- able gossamer threads. Aching and bruised, he retreated homewards, nor did his affairs ever prosper afterwards. ("Globe.")

div.head: SENTIMENT AND WAR.
div.p: Lieut-General Sir Ian Hamilton visited Birmingham last week in order to unveil a memorial erected in Cannon Hill Park to the local men who took part in the South Africant Campaign. In the course of an address, the General said more and more did civilisation seem to lay stress upon the value of life, until now even its most feeble and flickering mani- festation was jealously guarded from natural extinction. Yet let them pause and see by their side the revival of an Eastern civilisa tion which regarded life as utterly worthless, a breath, a bubble, compared with the national honour and the divinity of an Emperor. The Western spirit shuddered at the idea of death stalking grim and terrible over the stricken field; the other, he could tell them from his own experience, exulted at such a chance, at so rich, so supreme an opportunity. On the present occasion they felt there was something higher in this world than that modern senti- mentalism, which was sometimes akin to softness. The men commemorated, however poor and rough the conditions of their life might have been, yet cherished in the back ground of their thoughts an ideal, and that ideal was that they held their lives in fee for their King and country.

div.head: THE KORDOFAN RISING.
div.p: The sharp punishment inflicted by O'Con nell Bey on the brigand tribes of Kordofan should abate their craving for robbery and murder until its remembrance has grown faint. Had these pests got the upper hand even for a brief time, all the local forces of lawlessness -hey are exceptionally large would have rallied to the winning side, and Kordofan might have again become the home of Mah- dism. That sort of danger is always present in the outskirts of the Sudan, especially on the west side; the tribesmen are not only fiercely fanatical, but greatly. given to the acquisition of other people's property by violent methods. But it should be of happy omen that the Bag- gara clans, the ravagest and most predacious of all, instead of joining the rebels, hunted them into the desert, and thus allowed time for Governor O'Connell to effect the relief of the little beleaguered garrison at Talodi. We may pretty safely count upon the emission by Mr. Byles and his colleagues of vebement pro- tests against the slaying of such dove-like innocents. But these Radical outpourings of spurious humanitarianism have largely lost their vogue in Parliament, as have the exag- gerated lamentations of the Aborigines Pro- tection Society. What British civilisation has- on its hands in the Sudan interior is the crushing of lawlessness by whatever methods seem calculated to prove most effectual. That is the only sound foundation on which to build op order and peaceful industry. The overthrow of the Khalifa at Omdurman was only the begin ning of that process.-(Globe.")

div.head: FEEDING AN ARMY.
div.p: The continued flow of evidence as to the mismanagement of war stores in South Africs serves to glorify Wellington by contrast for the way in which he managed these matters. High as he always rated Napoleon, he con- sidered himself the better man of the two at feeding an army. His own losses, he used to say, would have been infinite'y greater but for his attention to the subsistence of his men. "The French armies ware made to take their chance and to live as they could, and their loss of men was immense." It struck him as very singular that in every history of Napo leon's campaign which he bad read this very serious feature had never been clearly shown "anything like its full extent." So he put it.

This question of feeding once led Earl Stanhope to remark to the Duke that it was strange that the French should have subsisted at Santarem so much longer than could have been expected. "It could hardly have been called subsisting we oquld not bave subsisted in that country," answered Wellington. It could only have been done by that system of utter disregard of human life which prevailed in the French army." And he recalled a letter which he had received from a Portuguese gentleman residing at Santarem." I had a cat," it rar, "and Heaven forgive me if I do them an irjastice, but I do believe the miscreants have eat him Following the signature was a pregnant addendom: "P.S.-I find that they have eat him f

div.head: INTERNATIONAL COTTON CONGRESS.
div.p: THE SUPERIOR PACKING OF EGYPTIAN YARN.
The third International Congress was open-
England, nine Euro- United States and

ed at Bremen last week. pean nations, and the India being represented. The delegates num- ber 210, which is 60 more than at Manchester last year. Four nations are represented in addition to those which sent delegates to the Manchester Congress.

Herr Ferd (Germany), who presided, ex- tended a hearty welcome to the dele gates. He said he was pleased to see so many delegates from England and France, where certain exchanges existed, and hoped they would gain valuable information at Bre- men, where a certain exchange was worked by merchants and spinners on equal terms. He remarked that foreign papers some- times wrote about. German competition, not always in a friendly manner, but he held that nearly all progress in the industry could be traced to competition, which kept people fresh and industrious. What was needed was the removal of ill feeling sometimes apparent in competition between nations, and far-seeing men had been working strenuously of late to secure this end, holding that the chief guaran- tee of the peace of the world was a promoter of international industry to secure permanent goodwill. Matual respect must prevail always and everywhere between nations, and in promoting goodwill congresses of men engaged in one industry were of incalculable value.

Mr. Macara (England). dealing with the work of the Committee and the Congress during the year, said the International Federation might claim to have justified its existence, as it had materially mitigated difficulties created by temporary shortness of supply of cotton, and had prepared the way for the subsequent prosperity of the trade. It became clearer each succeeding year how hopeless it was for an individual asscciation, or even a ration, to deal single handed with vast issues which affected more or less the destinies of the many millions who were dependent on the cotton industry. In a friendly meeting of the men of different nationalities, all engaged in the same industry, would be found the best means of dealing with difficulties and dangers of remov ing national jealousies and promoting peace and goodwill.

Mr. MacAlister (England), reporting on the visit he and others paid to the Southern States of America last year, said that in America little or no attempt was made to protect cotton from the westher after it had been picked, and in consequence it need surprise no one that European spinners had to complain of exces sive moisture in the cotton. The attention of the Southern Planters' Association was called to this and other defects, and a Committee composed of these gentlemen recommended that sheds and warehouses to protect the cotton be erected, that all bales be of standard dimensions, that all cotton be sold by weight, and that cotton b3 baled in lighter material. Owing to the superior packing of Egyptian cotton the coat of freight from Alexandria to Liverpool was 18c. per 100lb., while from New Orleans to Liverpool the cost was 30c. per 100lb. A reduction of 5c. per 100b. would effect a saving to European spinners in ocean charges alone of £3,500 annually.
The discussion on the subject was adjourned.

div.head: THE PLAGUE TERROR.
div.p: INFECTED RATS AND THE SPREAD OF DISEASE.

Early last year the Secretary of State for India, at the instance of the Royal Society and the Lister Institute, appointed a small expert committee, headed by Dr. C.J. Martin, director of the Lister Institute, to inquire into the natural history of plague and the scientific problems connected with its pro- pagation and dissemination, in the hope that, if knowledge on these matters could be secured, some progress might be made in the practical methods of combating the disease. The investi gations of the committee have been chiefly carried on in the Parel laboratory, Bombay, and the "Pioneer" states that it now seems likely that the whole problem of the disease will turn on the species of rat and rat flea which carry the infection. Dr. Martin is reported to hold that whether plague be primarily a rat disease and epidemics among human beings merely a participation of man in what is scientifically known as the epizootic, the intimate relation- ship of the two is undoubted. Hence there are the strongest reasons for beliewing that infec ted rats are the most important cause of the epidemic spread of plague. The common Indian (the black variety) has the habit of climbing and lives in the roofs of hats as well as in "runs." It is thus always on the move among human beings, and proofs continue to accumu- late that the conveyance of the plague bacillus to man is mainly from the rat or his parasite the fles. The germs of infection may be absor bed through abrasions of the skin or be taken into the system with focd, while the flea that has become infected undoubtedly carries the bacillus into healthy living bodies, as nume- rous experiments with rats have shown. Such questions as the habits of rats and their breeding seasons, and the existence of subacute or chronic plague among them in the hot months when the disease is not epidemic in Indis are being closely studied by the com- mittee. From 500 to 1,000 rats have been examined in the most elaborate way, and the existence and extent of the disease throughout the year will thus, it is hoped, be determined. The "East-India (Progress and Condition)" report, lately presented to Parliament, shows that during the seven years 1899 1905 the total recorded plague mortality in India was 4,059,800, the deaths registered in 1905 being 950,600, as against 1,144,900 in the preceding year.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
